P006073.project_name: Industrial Development and Export Promotion Project

keywords.cdata: accounting,Agricultural Credit,agriculture,assets,Auditing,balance of payments,bank lending,banking system,capital flight,Central Bank,collateral,competitiveness,Consumer Price Index,deposits,economic development,EIB,Employment,excess liquidity,expenditures,export growth,Exports,Financial Institutions,financial management,financial resources,FINANCIAL SECTOR,fishing,food production,foreign exchange,free trade,GDP,GDP deflator,GDP per capita,growth rate,housing,imports,income,industrialization,inflation,inflation rates,Insurance,insurance policies,interest rate,Interest rates,labor force,laws,legal provisions,legislation,lending rates,living conditions,migration,monetary policy,money supply,mortgage banks,oil,policy instruments,population growth,private commercial banks,production inputs,Productivity,reserve requirements,savings,savings deposits,small business,subsidiaries,subsidiary,Technical Assistance,Treasury Bills,unemployment,unemployment rate,value added,working capital

project_abstract.cdata: The project's objectives are to generate foreign exchange and to increase employment by expanding industrial output and exports and would consist of: (a) an investment promotion program and the construction of industrial estates through the BIDC; (b) industrial lending for fixed assets and permanent working capital through the BDB; (c) promotion of manufactured exports, training and marketing assistance to domestic exporters through the EPC; (d) management and vocational training for industry through BIMAP and the NTB. The project will not be subject to any extraordinary risk. BIDC's proposed policy for increased rental rates of factory space, to enable it to generate a positive rate of return, may reduce the demand for space in Barbados. This reduction, however, is not expected to be large as the rentals will still be in line with those charged by BIDC's competitors in the Caribbean.
